text: Half our karaoke party is missing.
- Ronnie, pull the car over now.
- Why is it just those four missing?
Hey, help! I found her on the floor.
- Hi, this is Dr. Bloom from New Amsterdam Hospital.
I'm trying to track down a veteran in your system.
Would you please call me as soon as you get this?
I'm, uh, I'm getting worried over here.
Who is this? - Dr. Lauren Bloom.
You were with my friend Casey Acosta last night
and now we can't find him.
Is he--is he with you? - Uh, no, ma'am.
We, uh...we kinda got into it last night.
And, uh, we almost got into an accident
and he just bounced. Who is this again?
- Dr. Lauren Bloom from New Amsterdam Hospital.
I did--I did see Casey last night.
We, uh, we went for a drive.
I'm going out to find him.
- Out, like out of the hospital?
Tell me where you last were there.
Hey, I got her. I got her.
- Not that I can see, but she's hypothermic
and we gotta get her out of here now.
Make sure we're the only ones here.
- Uh, Karen, come look at this.
- Ah-ah, just lie there. Don't move.
- The apartment's all clear. - Thank you.
- We found Thanatophol in your blood.
Happened last night at the bar.

It happened to Wilder, Trevor, Mia, Casey.
- Oh, my God. - We're getting the word out
to everybody, but right now you're my priority,
which means getting you fluids and rest.
- Oh, I'd rest a lot easier if my leg wasn't killing me.
- We got more of her labs back.
- I am ripe for severe DIC.
You need a body scan now. Walsh, let's move.
- Two surgeries, that's not too bad.
I swear to you I'm not cheating on you, mate.
It's where the paramedics took me.
- So I'm sure you know by now
that you were drugged last night.
A bunch of us got dosed unfortunately.
- Damn. The last thing I recall
I was on the train home.
Good Samaritans found me passed out like a real derro.
- And are you hurt? Are you okay?
Thank you for checking up on me.
- Yeah, yeah, yeah. No, of course.
I've been, you know, I've been really worried.
- Yeah? - This is gonna sound stupid.
I have a little bit of the old brain fog myself
You know, anything less than professional
- Sounds like you got it worse than me, mate.
That was it. We parted ways.
I mean, all, you know, all druggings aside.
- Okay, well, you rest up and feel better.
And, uh, just let me know when they release you, okay?
Yeah, I didn't forget. I just--it's been a crazy day.
- Here, grab the far end of this warming blanket.
Hook her up to a Level 1 rapid infuser.
She'll need Amp, Gent, and Dranova.
- Not Dranova. Chart says she's allergic.
Severe flushing. - Well, make it Vancomycin.
we're gonna have to be very careful, all right?
Just one bump could stop her heart.
And we won't be able to restart it until she's warmed up.
I know that the clots are a problem
and that I have to do something about them.
But I wanna try something less invasive.
I'm gonna try and break them up,
so can you put me on a regimen of Platazel?
- Platazel could lead to uncontrollable bleeding.
- As a hematologist, I am aware of the risk.
- Yeah, and this seems like an unnecessary one.
And surgery would mitigate a lot of these issues.
- Yeah, and it will permanently change my body
That's gonna permanently change my future.
And I can't help but think of the fact
on people who look like me.
well, that's feeling pretty risky to me.
And none of that is gonna be mitigated.
I do, but we're talking about your case.
Your body had an extreme reaction
to the Thanatophol, and you wanna add Platazel,
And if it doesn't work, then we're gonna have
to rush you into an even riskier surgery.
- Max, please. - And I don't wanna do that.
It's like a roofie on steroids.
- Someone really wanted to knock you all on your asses.
- Or kill us. - Who would do this?
I'm calling the police. You rest.
- I'm gonna order a CT scan of your head.
- This is where his idiot friend said he left him.
Okay, uh, let's just look for any sign of him.
His wallet is like old, and brown, and crappy,
and his phone is like from 2017.
What's going on with your visa?
- There was a glitch in my paperwork.
And I never got any of the notices
because I was living in my car.
And in the middle of all that, my case officer changed.
Bottom line, my refugee status is being revoked.
And if I don't fight it, I'll be sent back to Pakistan.
- You need to contact Legal Aid immediately
I'm not the only one this is happening to.
I know, I know, but just...
- Okay, it looks like the screwdriver sealed up

Casey? Casey, can you hear me?
- No, no, no, no! Damn it, damn it!
He's bleeding out. - I need a suture.
Anything. Anything to seal up the wound.
I need you to stay still, buddy.
- What the hell happened to you?
- Okay, you know there are easier ways
to get a day off, right?
- Okay, I just need to get in that hole.
- Come on. Stay with me, buddy.
- Mr. Higbee says, "If you're not early, you're late."
- Oh, Mr. Higbee sounds like a real stickler.
- We'll make it in time, hon. Don't worry.
- Uh, our daughter is ten feet in front of us.
I'm just saying that whatever you think you overheard
back there, it was not what it sounded like, okay?
- 'Cause it sounded like you hired Trevor,
the guy who hit on you during his interview,
the guy we both agreed you shouldn't hire.
That--that part is exactly what it sounded like.
But the rest of it-- - Stop. Just stop.
- Honey, please-- - No, no, I am not gonna have
a conversation with you about your infidelity
out on the street between here and PS 144, so just park it.
If not for me, then for our daughter.
then I think it's only right
that you and I raise the child together.
Claude can take the job in Denver
and, you know, we can stay together.
the three of us could raise the baby together?
- And what, I move to Denver?
Would we go to church together?
Claude and I could raise the baby without--
I just, you know, I had to--
I had to-- - Any other options?
Then there would be nothing tying us together.
- Then where do we go from here?
- So I just spoke to Dr. Malvo, who told me
that the clot busting is working.
- Yeah. You don't seem, uh, elated.
- It's just this isn't quite how I imagined
our first ultrasound as a couple.
Totally thought it would be your gallbladder.
Look, I know that we haven't discussed this,
and I don't mean to just spring it on you--
- I wanna have a baby with you.
- I mean, who even knows if it's possible.
- Let's not go there right now. - My--
- Let's just live in the possibility.
- And we already have like a million baby clothes.
- Yeah, and a crib. Got that.
- The baby practically pays for itself.
- Yeah, and this baby would be a little mini-you,
I had a whole plan to propose to you.
Nice reservations at this fancy restaurant
and a walk through New York City
You know, I even got a ring.
Maybe this place is as good as any.
Will you make me the happiest man
- Yeah, I got a ring. I got a ring.
It's nice. Should I get it?
I should go get it, okay. - Yeah, yeah.
- Yeah, yeah, okay. I'm gonna get it.
- I'm not--no, I didn't. I'm not saying that.
- Say that. - He has once again steered
the fight away from the real issue at hand.
- No, the real issue, as I see it,
is that you have a ton of hot gay friends
and I have never once-- - What?
- Insinuated that you might be sleeping with one of them.
But that's exactly where you went with me.
That's the first place your mind went.
- My friends' hotness isn't a secret.
You and I talk about how guys look all the time.
- Yes. - Yet this guy has been
yet you've never mentioned him once.

between the two of you. - Because--

You did that all on your own. - How can you--
That's the extent of our relationship.
I don't even know the guy's last name.
Does it bring me pleasure that this handsome guy
flirts with me? Yeah, sure, I'm a human being.
But it's harmless. - But it isn't harmless!
- You've been different these past few weeks.
I've noticed it. The kids have noticed it.
And I just assumed it was you getting back
Finding joy in this amazing life
No, but the thing that's been bringing you
all this joy these past few weeks
is flirting with another man at work
- If you still think that's nothing,
you're not just lying to me.
Excuse me. Someone's gotta start dinner.
You know why you're gonna be okay?
Because I wore a freaking taco hat for you
and that can't be the last humiliating thing
that you make me do, okay?
- It makes me really happy to see you and Leyla together.
- Yeah, I mean, she's talking to me again.
yeah, I feel pretty good about it.
If I die, you're gonna feel really bad about lying to me.
I've lost one and a half units of blood
and the only thing that's keeping me
If I was some random patient that got wheeled into your ED,
I don't think you'd be so sure about how this is gonna go.
- Leyla's immigration status is in trouble
and she has asked me for money.
- The good news is you have a lot of it.
- If I give it to her, then she'll get to stay.
But then our entire relationship is transactional
and eventually, she's gonna resent me for it.
- Well, then she's gonna have to leave the country.
And I'm never gonna see her again.
- Guess money doesn't solve every problem.
- That would appear to be the case.
Her body temp's 92. Still too cold.
Look, her heart is not going to restart
until we get her to a normal body temp.
- That's what we've been doing. - Well, we need fast acting.
- Give her 10ccs of Dranova. IV push.
- An allergic reaction will raise her body temp.
- Yeah, or it'll kill her. - So will arguing with me.
Doc from last night, what can I get you?
I don't know what you're saying,
but you gotta get out of here.
I got COVID, and it was nothing but a bad cold.
But you doctors, you exaggerated everything.
You scared people. You shut down businesses.
I was outta work for 18 months!
- You didn't lose your job, did you?
You know what it's like to owe a year of back rent, huh?
- Yeah. Yeah, I did it. I drugged you
and I hope you suffer the same way I suffered!
- Stop right there. Stop right there.
- Give me a tidal volume 700, respiratory rate 12.
- Lyn, what happened? - And five PEEP.
One of the clots broke free and is lodged in her lung.
We need to do an embolectomy now or she's going to die.
- She's in full anaphylactic shock, Dr. Reynolds.
We need to reverse the allergic reaction now.
- She's not warm enough for us to shock her heart yet.
Give her the EpiPen! What are you waiting on?
- Yeah, seemed better than a hammer and nails.
Jeez, no one in this department
- And looks like the carotid artery's intact.
I swear I'm not trying to take advantage of your feelings or--

But I'm in awe of you.
Starting out in a new country.
Even when faced with obstacles that would probably break me.
And not just in the way that I know that I need to get over.
I love you as a person.

I'll give you whatever money you need.
You gotta get the clot out of her lungs.

is not one of your best ideas.

The hospital is full of unvaccinated people

I don't want people to know that I'm a doctor.

- I heard you saved Helen's life.
somehow it was my dad who made me who I am
I so want to be a father.
So there's no way I could abandon my own child.

I wouldn't be abandoning that child at all.
'Cause they would have a wonderful mother.
And be raised in a home filled with joy and love.

that when the time is right...
I get to tell our child who I am.
I get to be in their life.
